data.name: paragraph
data.body: A cell consists of two electrodes, positive (P) and negative (N), immersed in an electrolytic solution. The positive electrode has a potential difference \( V^+ \) relative to the adjacent electrolyte, while the negative electrode has a potential difference \( -V^- \). The electromotive force (emf) of the cell (\( e \)) is the sum of these potential differences:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When a resistor (\( R \)) is connected across the cell, a current (\( I \)) flows through it. The electrolyte also has internal resistance (\( r \)). When \( R \) is infinite (no current flows), the potential difference between P and N is equal to the emf (\( e \)):

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When \( R \) is finite, the potential difference between P and N becomes \( e - Ir \), where \( I \) is the current flowing through the resistor:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In practical scenarios, we neglect internal resistances when \( e \) is much greater than \( Ir \). The maximum current (\( I_{\text{max}} \)) a cell can provide occurs when \( R = 0 \), and it is given by:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: However, to prevent damage, the actual maximum allowed current is typically lower than this value.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Ohm's law (\( V = IR \)) relates the potential difference across the resistor to the current and resistance:
